latest news.eng_title: Uber Hires Tesla Veteran Who Was Previously Laid Off By Elon Musk: Report
latest news.summary: Uber Technologies has hired Rebecca Tinucci, a former Tesla executive, as its global head of sustainability. Tinucci will oversee Uber's transition to electric vehicles and lead the company's shift to a zero-emissions platform by 2040. According to Andrew Macdonald, Tinucci's experience 'will be an incredible asset to our team at Uber.' At Tesla, Tinucci supervised the Supercharging team and secured charging-station agreements with automakers like Rivian, Ford, and General Motors, enabling thousands of drivers to access Tesla's Supercharger network. Tinucci will begin her new role on September 16. Meanwhile, Uber's stock has gained over 64% in the past year, making it an attractive investment opportunity for investors.

latest news.eng_title: US Startup Failures Rise 60% in a Year, Threatening Millions of Jobs and Economy
latest news.summary: The number of failed startups in the US has increased by 60% over the past year, causing significant concerns for millions of jobs and the country's economy. According to Financial Times, this trend is linked to founders exhausting their funds raised during the 2021-2022 tech boom. With tightened investment conditions and rising interest rates, many companies have struggled to secure new funding and were forced to shut down. Carta's data shows that 254 venture-backed startups closed in the first quarter of this year, with bankruptcy rates seven times higher than in 2019. Additionally, venture capitalists are now demanding faster returns, as noted by Carta's head of analytics: 'Venture capitalists told you to grow at all costs, now they want you to be profitable tomorrow.' If this trend continues, it could have a significant impact on the US economy, with Morgan Stanley analysts warning that venture-backed companies employ around 4 million people. Recent quarterly reports from tech giants like Alphabet and Tesla have also led to a sharp decline in the stock market, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices falling 2.3% and 3.6% respectively, the largest drop since the start of the Russia-Ukraine conflict in 2022.
latest news.title: Число неудачных стартапов в США выросло на 60% за год

latest news.eng_title: General Motors to Cut Over 1,000 Jobs in Tech Division

According to the company, 'As we build the future of GM, we must simplify (our operations) to gain speed and excellence.' The layoffs are expected to affect around 600 employees at the Warren, Michigan site. latest news.eng_title: General Motors to Cut Over 1,000 Software Jobs
latest news.summary: General Motors is cutting over 1,000 jobs in software and digital service development worldwide, with half of the layoffs occurring in the US. According to a report by CNBC, around 600 jobs will be eliminated at the company's technology campus near Detroit. General Motors stated that the decision is necessary to simplify processes, become faster, and prioritize investments. The company emphasized that the decision is not about saving costs, but rather a result of a business field review following the departure of former Apple executive Mike Abbott in March due to health issues. Abbott's departure came after General Motors had to suspend deliveries of several models in the spring due to software quality issues.

latest news.eng_title: The Great Tech Reset: Unpacking The Layoff Surge Of 2024
latest news.summary: The tech industry has seen a surge in layoffs, with over 124,000 workers losing their jobs in 2024 alone. According to Layoffs.fyi, 384 tech companies have laid off employees this year, with companies like Intel and Cisco Systems announcing significant job cuts. The reasons for these layoffs are complex, but include inflation and higher interest rates, economic downturn and recession fears, the impact of artificial intelligence, pandemic over-hiring, and outsourcing and offshoring. The fallout from these layoffs is deeply personal and far-reaching, with highly skilled professionals facing an uncertain future. The handling of these layoffs has sparked significant criticism, with companies often leaving employees in the dark for weeks or even months. As the industry navigates these challenges, it's clear that the tech industry is at a crossroads, and the decisions made today will shape the future of the industry and the lives of millions of workers for years to come.

latest news.eng_title: Cisco Prepares for Second Wave of Layoffs in 2024
latest news.summary: Cisco is preparing for a second wave of massive layoffs in 2024, with thousands of job cuts expected. The company is shifting its focus to faster-growing areas such as cybersecurity and artificial intelligence (AI). According to Reuters, citing anonymous sources, the layoffs may be similar in scale to the 4,000 employees who were let go in February. The company's quarterly results are expected to be announced on Wednesday, and will likely include details on the new layoffs. As of July 2023, Cisco had around 84,900 employees, not including those who were laid off in February. 'Cisco, the largest manufacturer of routers and switches that direct internet traffic, is struggling with sluggish demand and supply chain constraints in its core business,' Reuters reported. 'This has prompted the company to diversify through acquisitions, such as the $28 billion purchase of cybersecurity company Splunk. The company is also trying to incorporate AI products into its offerings, and in May confirmed its goal of generating $1 billion in AI product sales by 2025,' the report added. This is not the first major layoff in the tech industry this year, with Intel cutting around 17,500 employees, or 15% of its workforce, in August. According to Layoffs.fyi, over 126,000 employees have been laid off in 393 tech companies since the start of the year.

news knowledge.eng_title: Rivian (RIVN) reports 'defining' Q2 2024 earnings with profitability in sight
news knowledge.summary: Rivian released its Q2 2024 earnings, reporting revenue of $1.158 billion and a net loss of $1.46 billion. CEO RJ Scaringe called the quarter 'defining' as Rivian aggressively cuts costs and eyes its first gross profit by the end of the year. The company expects to achieve a positive gross profit in Q4 2024 and reaffirmed its guidance of building 57,000 vehicles this year and earning $2.7 billion in adjusted EBITDA. Rivian also announced that its R2 model has 'well over 100,000' pre-orders and is expected to launch in early 2026, with production reaching 215,000 units annually. 'R2 is worlds different' than the Tesla Model Y, according to Scaringe. Rivian has introduced drastic cost savings measures, including manufacturing upgrades and supplier contracts, which are expected to continue as new tech rolls out.

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel Confirms Major Round of Layoffs, Affecting Around 15,000 Jobs
news knowledge.summary: Intel has confirmed a major round of layoffs, affecting around 15,000 jobs, as part of a plan to save $10 billion in 2025. In a note to employees, CEO Pat Gelsinger said, 'We must align our cost structure with our new operating model and fundamentally change the way we operate.' He added, 'Our revenues have not grown as expected, and we have not yet fully benefited from powerful trends like AI. Our costs are too high, and our margins are too low. We need bolder actions to address both, particularly given our financial results and outlook for the second half of 2024, which is more challenging than previously expected.' Gelsinger also announced that the company will offer a improved retirement package and a voluntary leave program for eligible employees. He stated, 'These decisions have challenged me to my core, and this is the hardest thing I've done in my career.' He emphasized, 'My commitment to you is that we will prioritize a culture of honesty, transparency, and respect in the coming weeks and months.' This is the second round of layoffs at Intel since the COVID-19 pandemic, following a 5% reduction in staff in October 2022. The company is trying to recover in the market, but it is not alone in the tech industry, as other companies have also announced massive layoffs and hiring freezes in recent years.
news knowledge.title: Intel Confirms Major Round of Layoffs, Affecting Around 15,000 Jobs

news knowledge.eng_title: Volkswagen Delays Next-gen ID.4 And Other EVs Due To Software Issues
news knowledge.summary: Volkswagen is delaying the launch of its next-generation ID.4 electric vehicle due to software issues with its Scalable System Platform (SSP) software. The delay, which puts the launch about 15 months behind schedule, is the latest in a series of setbacks for the automaker's software subsidiary Cariad. According to a report from Handelsblatt, the ID.4 was originally expected to debut in 2028, but is now slated to launch in 2029 at the earliest. The delay is part of a broader trend of software issues affecting Volkswagen's plans, including the electric T-Sport, which has been pushed from 2028 to at least 2031. Volkswagen has faced significant restructuring efforts at Cariad, including the potential layoff of up to 2,000 employees. The company has also announced a $5 billion investment in Rivian, with plans to build next-generation software-defined vehicle (SDV) platforms for their electric vehicles.
news knowledge.title: Volkswagen Delays Next-gen ID.4 And Other EVs Due To Software Issues

news knowledge.eng_title: Troubled EV Maker Rivian Lays Out Path To Profitability
news knowledge.summary: Rivian, an electric vehicle maker, has outlined a plan to achieve profitability within three years. The company expects to cut its bill of materials by 20% in the fourth quarter of 2024, making it profitable at the gross-margin level. The R2 line of pickup trucks and SUVs, set to launch in 2026, is expected to bring in another 45% reduction in materials costs. Rivian aims to become profitable on adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation in 2027. CEO RJ Scaringe emphasized the company's sense of urgency in achieving profitability, stating that they are 'very, very fast driving towards the improvements necessary to get to positive free cash flow and, before that, positive margins this year.' The company outlined long-term financial targets of roughly 25% gross margin, 10% free cash flow, and adjusted profit margin in the 'high teens.' However, it did not set a timeline for achieving these targets.
news knowledge.title: Troubled EV Maker Rivian Lays Out Path To Profitability

The partnership will give Volkswagen access to Rivian's software and electrical architecture, and the two companies will jointly develop a new architecture. Volkswagen will invest $5 billion in Rivian between 2024 and 2026. The joint venture aims to create 'best-in-class software technology' and accelerate the development of software and increase scale. news knowledge.eng_title: Volkswagen Invests 1,000 Million Dollars in Rivian, Plans Joint Company
news knowledge.summary: Volkswagen acquired a 1,000 million dollar stake in electric vehicle startup Rivian and plans to establish a joint company that could increase investment to 5,000 million dollars by 2026. The automaker announced the deal after the market close on Tuesday, two days before Rivian's investor event, as the company has been trying to reduce costs and shore up cash amid slower-than-expected adoption of electric vehicles. With the acquisition, Volkswagen becomes the second traditional automaker to take a stake in the California-based company. Ford was one of the largest shareholders when Rivian went public in 2021, acquiring around 12% of the company. After the announcement, Rivian's shares rose 50% to $11.96 per share. Rivian's problems include a cash burn and significant losses presented since 2023. In the first quarter of the year, Rivian reported a loss of 1,450 million dollars and various layoffs. The company also reorganized its plant in Normal, Illinois, to launch updated versions of its R1T pickup truck and electric SUV R1S before the launch of its next generation in 2026. The company has been on a cost-cutting mission, even stopping the construction of a new multimillion-dollar factory in Georgia and cutting staff at its Illinois plant. These measures are expected to save the company around 2,250 million dollars in capital expenses, including the impact of starting production of the next-generation R2 vehicle.
